prompt: What option(s) of the ls command display recursive contents?
explain: The ls command lists directory contents. The lowercase -r --reverse option reverses the display order. The uppercase -R --recursive option displays subdirectories recursively. While most commands support a recursive option -R, the cp (file copy) command aliases both for convenience.

prompt: Which statement(s) are true regarding the kernel ring buffer?
accept: It is constrained by limited memory space
The oldest entries are discarded first
reject: It transports data packets across Local Area Networks
The grep command is used to access buffer entries
Entries persist after rebooting the system
Only the ring command may access buffer entries
explain: The Linux kernel initializes the kernel ring buffer as an early logging mechanism. Kernel modules, compiled or inserted, may verbosely add to the buffer. It is a limited size buffer because the early boot stage doesn't have access to disk storage yet. The memory allocated for the kernel ring buffer cannot be simultaneously used by programs.

prompt: Which application(s) are frequently executed by web servers?
explain: Websites with server side components frequently use ImageMagick to resize and crop pictures. For example, a forum may create avatars or thumbnails in smaller resolutions to reduce storage and transfer sizes. GIMP and Blender are multimedia applications for raster image editing and video rendering. The /etc/passwd file contains a list of user accounts. Ubuntu is a distribution based on Debian.

prompt: Which tar options(s) enable the bzip2 compression algorithm?
explain: The tar "tape archive" program supports mutliple compression algorithms including gzip, bzip2, and xz. Specifying the -j --bzip2 option outputs a bzip2 compressed archive during -c --create mode or inputs a bzip2 compressed archive during -x --extract mode. Related options include -z --gzip for gzip compression; -J -xz for xz compression; -v --verbose for increased verbosity; and -f <name> --file <name> to specify the archive file in context.
terminal: $PS1 tar -c -v -f archive.bz2 -j homework.txt ←

prompt: Which field corresponds to the UID of the /etc/passwd file?
explain: The /etc/passwd file specifies attributes for each user account in the system. Each field is separated by a colon ":" character. The format follows the USERNAME:PASSWORD:UID:GID:GECOS:HOMEDIR:SHELL specification. Environment variables expose the current user's home directory path via the HOME variable.

prompt: Which program displays kernel build information?
explain: The uname program displays version, release, and build information about the running kernel. Latest information about the Linux kernel project is available at kernel.org

prompt: What is the exit status given the command: cat /etc/skel/?
explain: Exit statuses, or error codes, are zero/non-zero values to determine if the previous operation was successful. A zero value indicates the operation was successful, whereas a non-zero value is an unsuccessful operation. Programs and scripts may choose what the status is for different scenarios.

prompt: Which database management system could be found in a Linux system?
explain: MySQL was released in 1995 as a relational database system. MariaDB forked from MySQL in 2010 due to licensing issues. PostgreSQL is another open-source database system with advanced workloads and cross-platform support.

explain: The passwd command has special permissions to update the /etc/shadow "shadow" file. Typical usage is to replace the one-way hashed passwords, but the --lock option prevents an account from further loggin.

prompt: Programs send error messages to which channel?
explain: All processes have three channels: standard input, standard output, and standard error. A file descriptor represents each of the buffers: 0, 1, 2 respectively. IO redirection syntax is written as > to redirect standard output while overwriting the destination; >> to redirect standard output while appending to the destination; 2> to redirec tthe standard error channel. Channels can be combined and piped as well. The 2>&1 syntax smashes standard error (2) into standard output (1).
